1. Use Arrays.asList()

Let's first looks its JAVA API below. We get that it returns a **fixed size List** 

 1 @SafeVarargs
 2 public static <T> List<T> asList(T... a)
 3 Returns a fixed-size list backed by the specified array. (Changes to the returned list "write through" to the array.) This method acts as bridge between array-based and collection-based APIs, in combination with Collection.toArray(). The returned list is serializable and implements RandomAccess.
 4 This method also provides a convenient way to create a fixed-size list initialized to contain several elements:
 5 
 6      List<String> stooges = Arrays.asList("Larry", "Moe", "Curly");
 7  
 8 Parameters:
 9 a - the array by which the list will be backed
10 Returns:
11 a list view of the specified array

We have two ways to use it.

1) The first way is call asList(), in this way, the List it returns is fixed size. If you want to add new element to it, it will returns java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException 2) If you pass the return result of asList to the constructor of ArrayList, then you can add new element. Here is an example of these two ways. 
 1 String[] arr = {"one", "two", "three", "four", "five"};
 2 
 3 //way 1
 4 List<String> list = Arrays.asList(arr);
 5 System.out.println(list);  //[one, two, three, four, five]
 6 list.add("six"); //java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
 7 
 8 
 9 //way 2
10 List<String> list1 = new ArrayList<String>(Arrays.asList(arr));
11 System.out.println(list1);  //[one, two, three, four, five]
12 list1.add("six");
13 System.out.println(list1);   //[one, two, three, four, five, six]

2. Use Collections.addAll()

In this method, you can create an List with size of the array. But you can also add new element later. Here is an example:s

1 String[] arr = {"one", "two", "three", "four", "five"};
2 List<String> list = new ArrayList<String>(arr.length);
3 Collections.addAll(list, arr);
4 System.out.println(list); //[one, two, three, four, five]
5 list.add("six");
6 System.out.println(list); //[one, two, three, four, five, six]

Additional notes

In above example, element in the array are objects, if we just have an int array, then we need special ways

1 int[] arr = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};   
2  List<Integer> list = IntStream.of(arr).boxed().collect(Collectors.toList());
